body: +1 After initial enthusiasm, I went back to css styled hrefs in all of my use cases due to this.
I have faced same issue and reach out this page now. Do we have a solution now?

Following, I have faced this issue and would love a fix :)

> The same goes if several files can be downloaded

I have three files available for download on [my Hugging Face App](https://huggingface.co/spaces/pleonova/multi-label-summary-text) and it's frustrating for the end user to have to run the application three times to be able to actually download each of those files.
Following, as I'm also encountering this issue.

How about semi-solution heavily based on [this](https://discuss.streamlit.io/t/creating-a-pdf-file-generator/7613/2?u=volodymyr_holomb): ``` import base64 import time import streamlit as st import pandas as pd def long_computation(): time.sleep(15) return pd.Series(range(1000), name='number') @st.cache def convert_csv(data): return data.to_csv(index=False).encode('utf-8') def create_download_link(val, filename): b64 = base64.b64encode(val) return f'Download file' st.write(' ... doing long computation ...') res = long_computation() st.success('Long computation done!') csv = convert_csv(res) download_url = create_download_link(csv, 'test') st.markdown(download_url, unsafe_allow_html=True) ```

issue.title: st.download_button() should not rerun the entire page

labels.name: type:enhancement
labels.description: Requests for feature enhancements or new features

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit â€” A faster way to build and share data apps.

issue.body:
Hi folks, 

Please, consider the MWE below: 
 ```
import streamlit as st
import pandas as pd

with st.form(key='form1'): 
    user_input = st.text_input("Insert text")
    submit = st.form_submit_button("Submit")

if submit:    
   st.warning("This part should not be lost after clicking the download button!")  
   st.write(user_input) 
    
    # Save dataframe as a .csv file
    df = pd.DataFrame({"v1": [1,2,3]})    
    file_name = "df.csv"
    file_path = f"./{file_name}"
    #
    df.to_csv(file_path)   
    # Create Download Button
    file_bytes = open(file_path, 'rb')
    st.download_button(label='Click to download',
                        data=file_bytes, 
                        file_name=file_name,
                        key='download_df')
    file_bytes.close()
```

### Problem

`st.download_button()` reruns the entire page, erasing everything that was opened after clicking "Submit". 
This behavior can be problematic, specially for applications that use `st.form()` like this one.

### Solution

Having an option in `st.download_button()` to not rerun anything would be really great.

Thank you

body: Also look at the comments in #3832, which is an older dupe of this issue (closing it since it has less upvotes).

> How about semi-solution heavily based on [this](https://discuss.streamlit.io/t/creating-a-pdf-file-generator/7613/2?u=volodymyr_holomb): > > ``` > import base64 > import time > import streamlit as st > import pandas as pd > > > def long_computation(): > time.sleep(15) > return pd.Series(range(1000), name='number') > > > @st.cache > def convert_csv(data): > return data.to_csv(index=False).encode('utf-8') > > > def create_download_link(val, filename): > b64 = base64.b64encode(val) > return f'Download file' > > > st.write(' ... doing long computation ...') > > res = long_computation() > > st.success('Long computation done!') > > csv = convert_csv(res) > > download_url = create_download_link(csv, 'test') > > st.markdown(download_url, unsafe_allow_html=True) > ``` Is this the solution that made you close the other issue @jrieke ?
No, I closed it so we don't have the same issue twice on here.

+1 to having more granular control over whether or not each button reruns everything.

I find myself frequently making cache workarounds, and in my specific case this time, I can't cache folium map objects so I just have to accept that the download_button resets everything

issue.title: `st.download_button`: Create downloadable data only when button is clicked.

labels.name: type:enhancement
labels.description: Requests for feature enhancements or new features

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit â€” A faster way to build and share data apps.

issue.body:
### Problem

`st.download_button` has a parameter `data` for the data to be downloaded, but this requires the data to be generated when the button is defined. This is not very efficient if the user doesn't use the download button: the data is generated and held in memory, but it is never used.

I'm working on an app that generates a DataFrame (based on data uploaded by the user) and I want to offer the option to download this DataFrame as a CSV file. I expect that most of the time users won't download the file, though, they'll just look at the data in the app. In such cases, there's no need to generate the CSV data (and consume memory in the process).


### Solution

Conceptually the best way, I think, would be to allow the `data` parameter to be a function that generates the data to be written, and to call that function only if the download button is clicked.


### Additional context

Note that this issue is not the same as issue #4382, (although I guess it is somewhat related).

There is a workaround to this issue [in the forums](https://discuss.streamlit.io/t/download-button-data-parameter-issues/34767/20), but IMHO it's not ideal, because it requires the user to click two buttons: one to generate the file to be downloaded, and a second one to actually download it.


---

Community voting on feature requests enables the Streamlit team to understand which features are most important to our users.

**If you'd like the Streamlit team to prioritize this feature request, please use the ðŸ‘ (thumbs up emoji) reaction in response to the initial post.**

body: having download button that fills memory even when not used and reloads page when clicked makes download button quite useless for any large-content or multi-content scenario
